When money is an issue, SSTO can NEVER work.
We're still not even using the correct launch profile -- if money is an issue.
The ideal profile -- to orbit -- is at least two-stages.
The first stage should be entirely oriented towards escaping Earth's atmosphere -- and nothing much else.
That means it will have a Blue Origin flight profile -- the pogo stick hop. This stage MUST use lowest cost propellants, too.
For lowest cost: that means LOX and Ethanol. Yes, it's primitive. Yes, it doesn't have a high specific impulse.
But it's CHEAP when everything is factored in. Brute force is a wonder all its own.
The upper stage merits LOX and liquid hydrogen or liquid methane.
Once entirely out of the atmosphere, a very high specific impulse does the trick.
Hydrogen /LOX is favored -- because hydrogen can be used as retro-fuel when returning from orbit.
A specific impulse of ~1000 does the trick. In this scheme, the vehicle never really gets ultra hot.
Instead hydrogen is heated in the nose (rather like the SR-71) to be exhausted in REVERSE at the rear of the descending machine.
One is not counting on air resistance. Instead, the velocity of orbit is killed by reverse thrust... a pure hydrogen gas jet.
By the time the machine has dropped low enough to really hit the exosphere, it's only going Mach 2.
It's been skipping high until then. Suddenly, exotic materials are not needed.
Towards the end, the second stage has the dynamics of a hydrogen dirigible. It falls like a feather... completely unlike any machine yet built.
Truax went down this road, and came up with mere steel for Sea Dragon.

The main reason, as far as I know, that ssto's are so viable in ksp is because heating is far less severe and air-breathing engines are extremely efficient compared to closed-cycle engines. Basically, the Skylon approach.

I think the video should be titled 'Why SSTOs suck ON EARTH' ;) There's nothing wrong with SSTOs on the moon, mars, asteroids, etc. in fact anywhere with low g and low/no atmospheric density. One implication of this is that once humanity has some permanent colonies on the moon, mars, space stations etc. the vast majority of astronauts will probably be born in the 'space colonies'. Why would you continue to lift anything out of Earth's gravity well once you have a sizeable population living in space and a decent amount of industrial, mining etc. capacity in situ? So the era of humans going into space from earth may only last a century or so. Just imagine if you were living on Earth 100 years from now and there is no earth-bound 'space program' as it is all being conducted by those already living in space.

The real reason SSTOs are so desirable in KSP is physics range limits and inability to control two craft at once. You need to take your first stage far enough to keep it out of the atmosphere while you get your upper stage to orbit anyway, might as well optimize it that last little bit for Kerbin's small size anyway. Without that limit, something like SpaceX's Big Fhecking Rocket makes more sense. (Until you want to be able to launch from anywhere and land anywhere, I suppose, but orbital inclination makes that harder anyway so stage 1 being fly to the equator, high, and fast and then launch also-reusable stage 2 is fine)

Some possibilities not examined:
A htohl spaceplane with either an aerospike or a combination of atmospheric and vacuum optimized engines that takes off from a runway, burns almost all of its fuel getting to high altitude, then throttles back as a tanker jet refuels it and it continues on to orbit.
Another concept is laser thermal rockets with ground based and/or space based lasers heating a liquid reaction mass to get the same thrust as chemical rockets but achieve much higher specific impulse, making your ssto simpler, smaller, and cheaper.

The rocket equation, while extremely useful, also makes certain assumptions that may not necessarily apply to an SSTO. First, one has to remember that the rocket equation was last formulated by Tsiolkovsky -- some basic versions of it go back much earlier -- in 1903, months before the Wright brothers proved the viability of mechanical flight. Chemical rockets are much older than airplanes, but if they were more fuel efficient for getting off the ground while still within our atmosphere, we would be flying around in jet packs, not jet planes. Second, the rocket equation is based on PROPELLANT-mass ratio, not FUEL-mass ratio, an important distinction, because a large amount of that propellent comes from oxygen, something which again, one is literally surrounded by when still taking off the ground. So, consider why current rocket design is inherently inefficient. Before launch, we fill a rocket engine full of the mass of hydrazine fuel AND oxygen, and then obtain all lift via direct thrust against gravity, immediately consuming that oxygen and not leveraging any other source of lift. First, address the lift issue. There is a reason Virgin Orbit is launching satellites from rockets launched from high altitude aircraft, because airplanes use less fuel to get you off the ground and shorten the trip the rocket has to travel. So the SSTO needs wings and horizontal takeoff. Second, there is no reason to fill an oxidizer tank on the ground for an engine that can start working as a traditional jet engine, using ambient oxygen while filling an initially empty oxygen tank in flight through freeze separation from the surrounding nitrogen. As speeds and altitude increase, the jet engine can convert to a ram jet engine, and later a scram jet engine to get to the edge of space and speeds of Mach 10+ before becoming a full fledged rocket engine and only THEN start consuming the stored up oxygen. Aerospikes can insure that the engine thrust is optimized for any altitude, further reducing the necessity of staging. Yes, while it would still be more fuel efficient to have this craft either detach from a mothership or shed some of its empty fuel dead weight in the form of staging, the inherent advantage of this craft -- that more than compensates for a diminished payload to fuel ratio, is that ditching stages or mating craft require anywhere from hours to several weeks to remate or replace, which means an SSTO's inherent cost savings would manifest in its ability to make several trips to and from space PER DAY. In fact, it is not even an SSTO that is so immediately useful as a single stage to SUB-orbit that could be used to ferry passengers from any point on the globe to any other point on the globe in an hour or so, revolutionizing commercial travel, the same way the jet engine did in the 1950s.

The Roton bears a marked resemblance to the DC-X. This is of course, because a bunch of the DC-X engineers went on to found the Rotary Rocket company. By the end, they had given up on using the rotor on takeoff, it would have been used only for aerobraking, and auto-rotation on the way down. After Rotary folded, most of those guys went over to X-COR.

Some other DC-X guys went over to Pioneer Rocketplane, which was planning to do in-flight refueling at 50,000 ft like a USAF bomber.

None of these schemes promised large payloads though. It was probably a coin flip if the DC-1 would have had a positive payload to LEO. They were chasing reusability, fast turnaround, and could have been very competitive for small scientific payloads. (Falcon 1 class payloads). But most important would be learning how to operate these vehicles.

Well, i keep comming back to this video! No doubt about it, my favourite Vehicle of Space History is the Space Shuttle Orbiter. And i keep comming the same conclusion every time, the real reason it was "dangerous" was the fact that it was truly an SSTO since it staged with the RSRBs and the external fuel tank. Both fatal dissasters were linked to these systems failing. And i keep thinking, well that was made with 60's and 70's technology advancements and hereditary of the Saturn V, surely if we redesigned the internals we could reduce some of the dry mass! What if for instance, though its not the best for the environment, instead of a huge compartment for cargo it was swapped out with SRBFUEL, Blowing the wings to a lifting body and adding hydrolox engines and a smaller tank optimised for the vacume of space on the trailing edges? Changing most of the internal dry mass from steel to modern composites, to reduce weight as mentioned before, reduced weight of the computers etc. with modern technology. changing the crew compartment to a smaller yet dockable size, for one use only: Shuttle to LEO. What if... this may very well be impossible, but it seems to me NASA tried to innovate too much from Shuttles to Venture Star all at once, instead of starting with the problems the orbiter had. Point is Airplanes where not without their faults in the beginning of the jet era either, critical crack distance on window frames exceeded, causing plaines to depressurize and plummit to the ground. Today's Dreamliners weren't build on 50's technology!

That aside, The Technology to get to Sci-fi like SSTO propulsion level tech, seems most likely to come in the form of turning energy into mass + speed. At which point a Nuclear Reactor, which changes nuclear mass into heat, could be utilized to transmute the fuel into hi-engery momentum capable material, with a non toxic exaust. What ever im rambling and it may seem like pseudo science, derived from quantum research at LHC in Cern. But considering anything in the universe as some form of energy, should allow for energy trasnmutation some day. The question is if we will ever be able to do it on vehicular scale. But... now we have a reason for a saucer Section: Hadron Accelerator Ring.

The ENTIRE point is that it utilizes lift from the atmosphere where it's available, as well as drawing oxygen from the air. Thus burning less fuel. I actually don't know how it lands, but I'm guessing after deorbiting it'll glide just like the space shuttle, once again utilizing the atmosphere. You get the point, obviously a rocket is better with stages, just look at Starship. But we have forces that can help lower fuel consumption when were closer to the atmosphere, that also allow us to launch with a less than 1.0 TWR. Why WOULDN'T you throw an aeroplane into space?? Skylon looks nice but SSTO Space Planes spend more time in the atmosphere and build up much more heat. I do prefer the SSTO SP method over the gravity turn of a rocket though. Holding at 20 degrees above the horizon will get you to space pretty quickly and efficiently but again you speed up much more in dense atmosphere creating heat and drag but it is still more efficient than speeding up after getting out of the atmosphere because you lose a lot of speed(deltaV) between ascent and circulation burns. I have been burning though my gravity turn recently. I ascend as normal until about 50-60k apoapsis (Physically 20-30k) then I begin to dip the nose about -10degrees below the horizon and it keeps my apoapsis from going much higher. The closer to 80 I get the more I dip the nose and it forces my periapsis out while holding my apoapsis where I want it and I don't use nearly as much deltaV by converting ascension deltaV into circularization. The angle is reversed to +10 degrees over the horizon once the apoapsis is reach. I have been able to hold at altitudes i like this way without the need to pro grade and retrograde nearly as much but back to SSTO's Re-entry is what worries me. You spend a long time aero-braking. I literally had to glide all the way in holding my non heat shielded belly up to create heat and drag to slow down..... It was a little scary. I didn't hit my engines until 2000 m to level my descent and line up with the runway.... It would have been awesome if I could have landed it without the need to level my decent but it was my first SSTO SP mission and I eyeballed it.... lol I was close though coming in hot belly up is a lot different than dropping in with a heat shield at just about any angle you want..... lol

In light of the mention of the LEM being an SSTO, only because it is launching from the moon, you should do a video on why a “Beanstalk” style Space-Elevator is not just “silly” to propose for Earth, but insanely and dangerously impossible.

I can’t recall his name, but he spoke at UCLA in the late-00s, or early-10s about “Space-Elevators” showing that an elevator could only extend into the upper-atmosphere of the planet.

And that trying to build one from the ground to orbit (or from orbit to the ground) was not just impossible, but insanely dangerous and impossible.

The forces exerted would be enough to overcome the strong nuclear force. And those would just be the vibrational forces created by the differentials in gravity and atmosphere, and not even the tension forces that would exist due to gravity. He said that were you to extend one of these things far enough down into the atmosphere the molecules in it would basically be torn-apart, possibly in a fission-reaction with non-fissile materials (basically a nuclear detonation from just the nuclei of molecules being torn apart)... But that long before you even got to that, the thing would have vibrated itself to pieces... Not as violently as a nuclear detonation, but still violently enough to turn anyone near it into people-soup... to say nothing of the hazards it would create to things in orbit.

Mars is basically about the upper-end of a planetary mass where a “Space-Elevator” could extend from the ground to orbit... And even then you kind of screw-up being able to put other things into orbit, as they would probably eventually wind up intersecting the elevator.

He said that even there... “Staged Elevators” were needed, and that physics just won’t allow us to get to space easily without “stages” whether it is rockets or elevators. He advocated various forms of “spinning/rotating” Elevators, where they would carry you to a higher orbit, where you would detach, and then use a bit of reaction-mass to get to an intercept with the next staged-elevator. Then you proceed to hook-up to it, rinse-repeat... Until you are in as high an orbit as you can get before you “leave orbit.” Then, you build stations at these points where you have fuel for maneuvering around the Solar System outside of all of those awful gravity-Wells.

I talked about this with Stan Love and Paul Abell (Both NASA guys... My brother used to be a NASA guy... He helped build the ISS, and worked on the curriculum to create the training curriculum for Astronauts). Paul has something to do with the Hayabusa, and some other outer-planet probes.

But the consensus was that it won’t be until we have fusion or antimatter to power such things.

They did point out that my idea about very high-altitude Airship platforms could produce a means of creating SSTOs (launching from about 75,000 feet, and then landing at “sea-level.” (On the ground).

But... Yeah... Differential Equations bite in terms of rockets.

Paul did point out some engines that were proposed for the Space Shuttle that had variable nozzles allowing them to be optimized for both atmospheric flight, and flight in outer space. I can’t recall what they were called.

As the guy who at one time was in charge of the Skylon airframe development, I can answer the point about skin heating?

The SR-71 used a conventional aircraft monocoque where the skin was the aeroshell and the load bearing structure and the fuel tank wall. With Skylon these three functions are separated. The outer skin which gets hot has expansion joints every 30 cm, this aeroshell is thermally isolated from the load bearing titanium truss structure, which then supports the separately insulated propellant tanks.

On the way up the high temperature regime is short enough that heat soak is not problem, on the way down although the low ballistic coefficient keeps the maximum temperature lower than the Shuttle the down side is that Skylon is in the high temperature regime longer and heat soak requires control. This excess heat is mopped up with 100 kg of liquid hydrogen from the orbital tanks.

In my opinion, we need to simplify rockets, not make them more complicated because complexity necessarily compounds the risk of failure. One way to do that is to use a partly evacuated hyperloop system. This would accelerate the rocket to supersonic velocities and, if built on top of a mountain, would also enable the first few kilometers of altitude (and denser air) to be left behind. Perhaps most importantly, it would also reduce vibration in those first few minutes of flight, where engine thrust and turbulence are greatest. Yes, a hyperloop system would be complex in itself, however risk is also reduced when a technology is mature; it could and should be exhaustively tested for ordinary transportation thousands of times. So this combination may not be ready for a while, but, like ion and solar sail drives for interplanetary travel, needs to be funded, improved, well tested and utilized.

Well there's other methods of launching SSTOs:


There's the Jules Verne Cannon: Want to get something close to orbit? Shoot it from a cannon! Too severe for anything fragile, but all the propellant remains on the ground. There might be a rocket on the package, but it only has to have enough fuel and thrust to make up for what the cannon can't do. The downside is it's a REALLY, REALLY big cannon.


There's also the Magnet Rail Launcher: Kind like using a magnetic rail train to get a SSTO flyer up to speed while still on the ground, except it's more of a sled than a full train. The world's fastest maglev train is 375 mph, but that's made for passengers and expected to travel over long distances. A platform made to launch an SSTO flyer can probably get even faster over a relatively short distance (several miles, most likely). You just need to build up enough electricity for each launch, perhaps from a hydroelectric power source, solar panels or a propane powered generator.

Hate to break it to you, but you’re completely wrong about why rockets are staged in the first place. Engines efficient enough can be built, and are built, to lift a rocket into orbit in one stage, but at great cost and with some difficulty. More important than that is how the engines are actually built. The bell nozzle on rocket engines allows the air pressure around that bell to exert a given amount of pressure on their exhaust. At low altitudes, a given bell might work very efficiently, but at higher altitudes, not nearly as well. Staging a rocket allows you to switch between engines as you ascend, so you always have an engine firing that works most efficiently in that environment, given the pressure on its exhaust.

An engine like, say, a linear aerospike fixes that problem completely, as it can change its geometry mid-flight. Since an aerospike is also a bit lighter per pound of thrust than a conventional, bell-nozzle engine, the extra weight of multiple stages carrying the fuel needed for the extra engines I noted is unnecessary. Using an engine like this in an SSTO would be completely reusable, demolishing one of the greatest barriers to space travel; Cost. Such a craft could lift a similar amount of cargo as a larger multi-stage rocket, but at a fraction of the weight itself.

So while some SSTO designs might suck, no, the concept of the SSTO doesn’t suck, and we actually know that some versions would be superior. Maybe instead of searching for a title that would get you clicks, you should’ve searched for some more data on the thing you chose to claim “sucked.”

Enjoyed the vid, but to be fair the current missions of SSTO and MSTO differ. MSTO is the most efficient (with today's tech) to launch packages into earth orbit, a properly designed SSTO with a hybrid Aerospike engine will be more efficient at launching from earth and then piggy backing on to an interplanetary propulsion module to explore other planets/moons. What folks need to understand is that the mission defines the "system" solution. So if you are looking for a space exploration vehicle that can accommodate various missions, then I can easily see SSTO with hybrid propulsion solutions, with possible lifting body designs (again depending on the atmospheric environment). Oh and one last thing, technically the lunar lander was not SSTO since it left its landing module behind.

Will humankind ever have a reliable SSTO? Probably. I think it will be a variable-wing (think B1 bomber) space-plane design. I see it lifting off AND landing horizontally on airport runways. I see it taking off using conventional fuel+air jet engines until it reaches an altitude of about 12,500 meters (where the air starts to get thin), then converting over to fuel+oxidizer rockets to reach desired orbital speed and altitude. During the atmospheric part of its flight the wings will sweep further and further back as the speed increases as less wing area is needed for lift. (Of course, once outside the atmosphere, the wings are just "along for the ride".) To deorbit, it fires its rockets in a brief burn to cause it to start falling out of orbit, and once it reenters the atmosphere, it glides to a runway landing like The Space Shuttle did. (Or perhaps even does powered flight to an airport like an airliner.)

Pretty good talk. Sadly, you mention linear spike engines several times, but say nothing about them, though clearly they are an important part of your presentation. Yeah, I know, there are always things you have to leave out, particularly to an audience with little prior knowledge of your subject. You clearly know your rocket science. May I suggest a tip on teaching others? Thanks in advance. The first time you use a word that you don’t presume your audience knows, give a quick description. Doesn’t have to be a complete definition, just enough so they can follow your talk. If you can’t give a description of the word without bogging down, leave it out. If you can’t leave it out or describe it, or expect your audience to know it, you’re in trouble. Either re-scope your subject, or, in a pinch, mention and provide a link that will explain the word. That’s the way to go if you’re pretty sure most of your audience is familiar with the term, not so much if most people have to look it up. You’re doing a good job teaching something most people are interested in, but will never have the math or technical background to fully understand. Kudos. I think you could be genuinely great at this if you keep working on your presentation skills.

essentially, the problem with SSTO's is the engine (and subsequently the fuel) has to carry the exact same load throughout its entire journey. This means both the fuel and the engine has to be at least average in all conditions, which is difficult to achieve, but also means very low efficiency compared to specialised stages. With current tech, average is kinda not good enough, so we're going to have to wait with SSTO's until the best is astronomically better. In other words, multi stage specialisation is our best bet, for now.

Tim...SSTO's work. They always have and here's why. It's called backwards inventing (not backwards engineering). The example i like to use is this: At work, i'm not allowed to wear a watch since it might help get my hand and arm stuck in a machine and get me injured. So here's where reverse inventing comes in. I can't wear a watch, so i'll buy a calculator that has a time function: "Hey boss, now i can do tough math while working!". The Minuteman I ICBM had to be aligned to its launch azimuth before being ready for launch!  The metal ring on which the missile rested in the launch tube was capable of being rotated by the Combat Targeting Team from the equipment room around the upper portion of the launch tube.  But this only had a few degrees of movement.  In the event of a major retarget, a Missile Maintenance Team (MMT) had to be dispatched, two men lowered to the level of the ring in an elevator workcage, so they could rotate the ring and the missile to approximately the new launch azimuth. The targeting team then made the final adjustments.  Later models of Minuteman were aligned to true North, and would roll to the correct azimuth.

You make a strange argument against SSTOs here. If I'm understanding you correctly, your point of view is that they're really difficult so it's better to just use staged craft. Does that mean they're not worth pursuing? The benefits of a working SSTO would make for a revolution in how we get to orbit; an enormous reduction in waste, cost and required time between flights. You talk about how no one has made a working SSTO as evidence that they're terrible but in the same breath praise the BFR for being reusable despite it existing only on paper. You mention the X-33, a potential SSTO that was plagued with technical issues; those issues have since mostly been solved through manufacturing advances. Advances in ablation technology, engine design, and manufacturing all point to a working SSTO spaceplane that could be built right now if someone put up the money for it.


The reason no one has attempted a working SSTO thus far is because for-profit space companies don't want to put the fate of their company on an unproven concept. Government space agencies' budgets are also so hamstrung that they don't want to take that risk with the little operational money they have. The vast majority of the technology we use today for staged craft was designed and tested during the space race when cost was not really a factor. We need a second space race to open up the budgets of government agencies in order to make SSTOs a reality.

SSTO will become a more attractive option as material science improves because you don't have to lug around extra engines. In short, SSTO is not a pipe dream. It's an inevitability.

As long as we're dependent on chemical propulsion to generate enough thrust to push a missile into space, SSTO won't really work.

Propulsion systems with very high specific impulses exist, but they have very little thrust and usually only work in the vacuum of space. Propulsion systems that can overcome gravity need hundreds of tons of fuel and increase the mass of the spacecraft by a multiple of what you want to have in orbit. This is then all ballast during a landing and must survive the re-entry. If you want to take so much fuel with you that you create a braked entrance that does not involve any danger of burn-up, then you reach the limits of what is possible. Because even this fuel has to be dragged up first.

At the moment no physical principle is known that would make it possible to build a spaceship with which one could - as in science fiction filming - take off from a planet and land on it again. At best a kind of airplane is conceivable, with which one can create short hoppers from the athmosphere, which however would not be able to fly e.g. to the moon or to reach even a stable orbit.

Maybe at some point a second "Einstein" will come and find the world formula and a so far completely unknown phyiscal law, with which this can work.

But it doesn't look like that at the moment,

"SSTOs are bad because they suck when used like a rocket designed to have stages." Just like saying: "boats suck because if I put wings on them, they can't fly".

SSTO are the natural evolution of multi staging rockets. They are better under every aspect: cheaper, easier to maintain, totally reusable and they also respect one of the most important principle of engineering: "what does not exist (multiple stages), it cannot break ". The fact we're not already capable of building a fully functional SSTO does not mean that the concept sucks. It is a GREAT concept, but we still have some technical difficulties in practical design.

The "tyranny of the rocket equation" (Tsiolkovsky equation, for people who want to elaborate) does not say it's impossible to build an SSTO or that it is not convenient. It simply says that current rocket engines with current ISP cannot be arranged in a single stage to reach orbit. The problem can be easily overcome by using a higher ISP engine (or a fuel with higher energy density).
That said, no one said that we absolutely need to use a rocket engine as first stage as in the SABRE engine you presented.
We do not really have to immagine a "plane going faster than mach 3": we already have several fully functional mach 5 air breathing design and also a mach 10 (non air breathing) design. We also have designs capable of reaching mach 20 without structural problems.

In conclusion: it is obvious that, at the state of the art, SSTOs are not viable and convenient (or we would just use them instead of over complicated multi stage rockets). This does not mean that they sucks.

To whoever entered the captions:
1) Thank you! Too many let speech-to-text do the work for them or have captions turned off completely.
2) "Wah la" is spelled "voila." It comes from the French phrase "voi la" or "look there," as in "look at that." To anyone pronouncing it without the V, you're doing it wrong. (Slightly.) It should sound like "vwah la."





2a) Bonus: The aviation distress signal is not "mayday." It, too, is French, namely "m'aidez" or "help me." But, unlike voila, the pronunciation does, in fact, sound the way you're doing it. People have misunderstood this long enough for "mayday" to become an English noun meaning a call for help.
2b) To anyone who thinks French phonetics are crazy, remember we speak a language in which bough, cough, rough, and though do not rhyme.

Don't make it a SSTO yes or no decision based on the beauty of the pictures from stage separation; look at the reasons why staged rockets are used: No one actually tries create a SSTO with the aged (basically 1940ies) bell-shaped (or Laval) and thus highly inefficient rocket motors. BUT: if you use the almost completed X-33/venture star aerospike rocked motor ( the stopping reason was just the then non-secure (1970ies) composite fueltank NOT the linear aerospike), you are up to 30-35% more fuel-efficient with a more light rocket motor. Than you simply don't need more than one stage/motor, actually they just add weight. The empty fuel tanks don't compensate that advantage. Than you also understand that all the current SpaceX returning stages are just a way to somehow meet the need to reduce cost/payload while still using the today heavily tested laval motors and thus sticking to their design limits. Here's why the linear aerospike is stuck in developement: ARC just doesn't have the money to go big- their rocket is more a prove -of-concept, the x-33 data are not open source and Lockheed Martin currently are not working on carrier systems. And the other companies would have to dare to start all over again in the R&D cycle done in the 1970ies without being funded for it...Even Elon Musk (who considered the aerospike) shied away from designing the falcon around a whole new rocket motor design as he simply could rely on buying in the existing knowledge of traditional rocket motors to save time&money....which is the way to go if you run a private company: your decisions are not to be brave but create reliable capital growth for your shareholders.
See my argument is not simply pro SSTO - they are just a follow-up of using a linear aerospike: as they weigh less, are smaller and can vector/steer without major movable parts (like the whole nozzle section of the laval motors) than any of the staged, classic rockets. Sooner or later the trait of not creating more and more space garbage (Kessler- syndrome) will increase to the point that SSTO will become a must to secure future starts into space from our planet. And here getting everything back in one piece is a major advantage...and then consider atmospheric pollution:the X-33 only used H2/O2 as only fuel..!
It's like the decision whether to use for a car a diesel-motor with lots of additions to make it cleaner or switching to an electric motor altogether.

I strongly disagree SSTO is all about reusability, as much as I disagree the reusability is always the best way to go - the best example for this is the Space Shuttle - almost fully reusable but many times more expensive, complicated and ultimately unreliable than the simple expendable (multistage) Soyuz rocket. At the current level of material science, a reusable SSTO would certainly be a maintenance nightmare, much greater than the Space Shuttle, even if some huge advancement in rocket fuel would allow for such specific impulse increase to make dragging all dead weight of atmospheric engines and flight surfaces into space where they are simply not needed possible at all.


What I think could be theoretically feasible would be more like a huge cannon shell with an added rocket engine for sending very small and robust cargo into orbit. To get perspective into what I mean - an APFSDS fired from smoothbore tank cannon can travel at close to 2000 m/s. Railguns currently tested promise muzzle velocities well in excess of 3500 m/s. Anti-tank rockets are also being routinely fired from tank cannons (I imagine at significantly lower muzzle velocities than APFSDS rounds, but anyway that's a proof that a rocket, with all the electronics, sensors and guidance systems can survive being fired from a cannon). If we scale that up, we need a robust and cheap single stage rocket that can be fired from, say, huge railgun, to bridge the remaining 5000 m/s or so, but with the advantage that it already left the dense atmosphere before it ignites, so it can be optimized for space flight. Further advances in railgun technology, which is currently being actively researched by USA, China, and Russia for military purposes, can increase muzzle velocities far higher, which lowers demands for the single-stage rocket, all to the point when it retains only maneuvering engines. I found somewhere that it would be very cost-effective if the demand for sending material into orbit suddenly increased by orders of magnitude - such a system would cost a fortune to build, but it would have very small operating and reasonable maintenance costs. The trouble here is there is just no business model in sight that would require sending so much material into orbit.

You're not quite right with the Roton flight plan. Although earlier proposals for Roton used rotor tip rockets as the main engines, the final plan used something different. The rotors would only be used for landing, and the craft shown in the video was the approach-and-landing demonstrator.

(I was lucky enough to attend the rollout, and had a sit in the cockpit. It's bizarre. The pilots nicknamed it "The Batcave" because of the restricted view, and the flight handling was absolutely horrible.)

The main engine was the entire base of the vehicle, which rotated on one large bearing, which was the only moving part. The centrifugal force would pump the fuel and oxidiser to around 90 coke-can-sized combustion chambers at the rim, angled to maintain the rotation, and creating an aerospike engine. The idea was that this would be simpler and more reliable than turbopumps. The base also doubled as a heat shield, which would be actively cooled during descent.

So the flight profile was: spin up engine, ignition, launch, do one or two orbits while deploying payload, deorbit, re-enter base first and shed most of the velocity by aerobraking, deploy rotors, autorotate for most of the remaining descent, and then power the rotors for landing. Here's a video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=So3d_JfGrMQ

I believe that development was stopped due to combination of lack of investor confidence in the main engine design (the very final business plans suggested that proving flights would use a conventional engine), the reduction of the small launch market in the early 2000s, and the continuing refinement of small expendable launchers.

I watched your video with a smile. I like it, your arguments are sound. Honestly, it is a good video. However...
When developing technology to put something in space, we have to start pointing out that there is difference between people and other "stuff". We mainly focus on "other stuff" because we still do not have the people that can stand outer space conditions for a long time. Artificial intelligence is far more promising, and I am not talking about sentient robots. I am talking about huge algorithmic libraries with fast information processing.
Once you realize you want to put "stuff" in space and not necessarily people, as an engineer, your mind opens. There are three optimal places in the world to do so; they are near the equatorial line and at few thousands meters of altitude. You can run the simulations and find out how much these two factors increase the weight of the load. It is not neglectable.
The second aspect for consideration is the propulsion system. Anything that depends only on combustions is already the past. As you are not sending people, you can built accelerators (in principle no different from the particle accelerator in Europe). As long as you have enough energy (electricity), you can spend days accelerating whatever you want to send until you reach the proper velocity. This is very important because acceleration and velocity are not the same. Acceleration can be looked as a force that will impose severe structural constrains; velocity is somehow innocuous. There are still strong aerodynamic constrains but they can be solved with good design and a "front runner aerodynamic knife" that will facilitate the path the first thousands meters (In fact, the difference in air pressure created will help reduce the demands on the guiding systems).
The end of the journey will require an autonomous propulsions system for outer space conditions (minimal reaction mass).
For visualisation. The launch site consists of a huge eletromagnetic accelerator that ends in some sort of railgun. The "rocket" will be a protective carcasse with basic guiding systems. Guiding the "rocket" will be a spear-like object that has also been accelerated. It will "cut" the air to reduce resistance, ensure direction via differential air pressure and reduce physical demands (heat tolerance and strength) on the "rocket". The spear-like object will finally fall to Earth while the rocket continues its trajectory to outer space. Of course, the "rocket" is not a rocket but more of a missile.
Everything I am telling is already being researched or developped. And it is estimated a 20X-40X reduction of costs per kilo put in orbit. It has not advanced further because no country want to invest unless they have absolute control (geopolitical reasons). Moreover, the technology already exists but no country has it all (i.e. Russia is the leading nation in hypersonic aerodynamics but is far behind in electromagnetic acceleration).
As somebody will point out, I am not giving any evidence. However, if you do the research, you will find papers supporting what I am saying. I do not want to convince anyone. I just wanted to contribute to the discussion. I feel honest admiration for a guy that brings this type of discussions to youtube using the most basic communication tools. Respect.

I feel like you mostly ignore the effects of engine efficiency in this discussion. By using current conical engines, rockets have only limited peak efficiency per stage and increasing the amount of stages prevents the loss of efficiency by using a different engine cone. If aerospike engines were used, an overall higher efficiency is able to be reached when compared to 1 conical engine. Having 1 aerospike engine over 2+ conical engines could increase the overall efficiency of the rocket by not having to drag the extra engines around.
The main reason aerospikes aren't used atm is that they don't have the data and expertise behind them that conical engines do. If a company or research team would want to develop one today, a whole lot of extra experimenting and investing would have to be done. Without large budgets research teams won't do that and with possible red bottom lines, companies won't either.

Strictly speaking, SSTOs seem to be pointless for the prospects we see today. They need to overcome 2 basic factors:
1. Utility over dead weight. Like why would you need atmospheric engines in orbit? The only solutions would be: design an engine and/or fuel type that works both in orbit and in atmosphere, aka either have a self-oxydyzing fuel so you do not carry two types of fuel or create an engine that can take oxygen from atmosphere like a jet engine and then go into a rocket version, perhaps like a modified post-combustion thing. Or, you would create something that needs an SSTO with all the pain of carrying extra engines and fuel. Is there anything that requires something like that now? Not really. only purpose of rocket launches is payload delivery. Basically, your vehicle does not even need to return. Or only a small portion of it if it carries cosmonauts or astronauts.. What would require SSTO? Well, intensive exploitation of space. Aka establishing a mining colonoy or stuff like that. Then you would need cargo and passenger ships to take the stuff from orbit to the ground and so on. And here the reusability part comes into play. Or perhaps a troop transport for military aplications, like in star-wars.
2. Phyisics. Spacecraft tend to heat quite a lot. Space planes that try to gain a lot of speed in the atmosphere, even more (as explained in the video). The only way I could a space plane design work would be to find a way to lift that thing as high as possible, using as little fuel as possible. For example, I would be thinking of using the archimedic force, like weather balloons. Of course, this has a lot of problems. Like, first of all, size. Zeppelins were huge and could barely compare to a WW1 plane.

OK Bucky, apparently you didn't get the memo.

The SR-71 and A-12s used FUEL as coolant in flight. They heatpumped the heat in the instruments and everything else into the fuel system then dumped the now heated fuel into the engines (which made it burn even better) but when they were on the tarmac prior to flight or during testing they had to get rid of the heated fuel somehow. So they would just DUMP the fuel. Since a small port to dump the fuel would actually create a really nasty drag-heat point on the aircraft on the bottom or would drench the aircraft's body in fuel on the top (leading to massive explosions in takeoff) they let it drain out through one of the expansion joints on the lower body. In flight when they needed to dump fuel for cooling they just dumped it out the aftmost afterburner ring without ignition... but for the most part the aircraft never got hot enough at such low speeds and at the high speeds it was burning the fuel for thrust anyway. To keep the weight down and reduce any possibility of mishap from an additional cooling system they didn't bother to install one.

So yes, it did expand and contract with heat; and yes, it did drain fuel through the expansion joints on lower body panels on the ground but NO, it wasn't leaking out: Jet aircraft have to have PRESSURIZED fuel tanks in order to operate. If there was a leak at pressure either the engines wouldn't start or the pressure needed to force fuel flow would have been enough to dump almost the entire fuel load several times over prior to takeoff.

*THINK* before you believe bullshit on the internet.

Aerospike engines are really the only option for a true SSTO rocket platform. They are the only thing that are just as efficient at any altitude, the only limiter would be weight and having fuel that can withstand space if you need to relight it.... which is where things like TEB come in. The space plane idea of taking off on any runway and then climbing to altitude and somehow overcoming gravity is never going to work until we have engines that don't run on liquid or gas fuels but run on a clean fission reactor or something. The amount of fuel required to go from the ground to high altitude and the heat generated on the skin of the plane would make it a no go. It'd have to be WAY too huge to hold all the fuel and then it'd just be empty weight as your fuel got low. (look at how much fuel the SR71 guzzled and how it had to cope with heat at Mach 3+ and because it was so hot and flew so high it had to have a specially made fuel called JP7 and had to use TEB to light it's after burners... it also had special engines that were part conventional jet part ram jet) Now the plane carried aloft under the wing of another plane like the X15 and then launching to space would work, but that's not SSTO. 5 "how cares if it comes back in one peace or breaks of"
Well .. it do matter a lot from a engineering standpoint. This is where most the complexity comes in.... Yea sure, you don't have the reentry problem of the first stage.... But you will have it on the second anyway. Recovery is also easier

To make a usable ssto one have to be intelligent, not use brute Force. It don't work .. obvious.

Firstly is to bring down the thrust. This saves weight. Hence wings.
Secondly to push up IPC. And a tiny bit makes a huge difference. Saber is up to about 460, that is a huge improvement over 350 something that space X use... Of cause blue origin is a bit better.
Thirdly land areodynamicly.

A staged rocket will never be as cheap as a functioning ssto. A skylon have only 2 engines, with one turbopump each. Falcon 9 heavy have over 30. It don't matter if they are modular. That don't help Inspection. There is a reason pretty much all airliners have two engine.

More over a flying ssto use less fuel. Firstly it don't fight gravity , so it's not in a rush to reach space. That makes it fly slower (at every given altitude) also fighting less air resistance. It also need about 1/5 of the engine power... So it need to lift... Well 1/5 of the engine mass.

It needs 30% less fuel simply because it have higher IPC. It also need really no. Or very little landing fuel, saving a additional 5-10%.

The largest saving is to get to 30 000 meters and 5mach. While yes, this is only 20% of orbital velocity and about 1/3 of the way to space. This is the part that use the most fuel for normal rockets.

This combined let a ssto skylon style use less fuel than a Falcon typ two stager for same payload to LEO. (For high orbits it's a bit different). Also this aircraft could in theory do multiple runs per inspection, line a airliner. A minute stage rocket just can't.

There is a few more reasons. You really can't run a maned missing with landing on rockets. It's just to riskey. For bringing people back from space you either have to have a space plane or have a special reentry vihicle.

This gives us one additional advantage of a space plane. It can re-enter areodynamicly. This have been done ... Sort of with a esa test rig a few years back. Proven it can be done. NOTE. Space shuttle is NOT a space plane. It's a brick that looks like a aircraft. It don't do aerodynamic reentrys. It just fall down hoping not to burn up.

The nuclear engine is totally useless in ksp at ground level. It's because of game play reasons. The real engine worked just fine at sea level and could easiLy lift it self and fuel to get to orbit. We know that. Because it's not a paper product. It have actually been tested. (In bench)

It had a IPC of 800 (same as in ksp) but it thrust to weigh was actually almost 3 times higher than in ksp, and that is vacuum numbers.

This was a late 50-tys and early 60-tys tech. Later models have been simulated to have between 1600 and 3000 in IPC. That would pretty much Push down a ssto to the size of a cessna

Just thinking out loud: Could one say a two (or more) stage is a form of launch assist?

For that matter, could you call a rocket carried up to high speed + altitude on a jet aircraft and then released, a two stage?

Perhaps instead of STOs we should be going the other way round. Trying to maximize launch assist technology. With ideally the end result giving us something like orbital rings and have the rocket just carried into "space" on a railway track, then boosting it using electro magnets until it reaches orbital velocity or more. This way that rocket's fuel is reduced to only needing what's necessary for the return trip.

Of course such permanent launch assist structure is going to be extremely expensive. And depending on design is not actually possible (yet). E.g. something like a space elevator stretches even carbon nanotubes to their max and beyond. But there are some other designs which is theoretically possible with just metal alloys. Especially when considering ideas involving active structure strengthening like particle streams in a magnetic tube - which is then expounded to an orbital ring with an inner particle stream going in excess of orbit velocity and the outer shell hosting the magnets and in geo-sync with the planet - from which "escalator" bridges / cables can then tie back to the surface.

Though I'm guessing this is exorbitantly expensive and would require many times more traditional rockets to get all that stuff up there in the first place. I do think that the eventual saving on future launches would give some break-even point.

What would make this actually viable is to rather just build a moon base and then mine the materials for the ring from there. It would be much cheaper to launch from the moon and fly the parts into the wanted earth orbit.

Everyday Astronaut, in as much as ARCA's HAAS 2C rocket, it's being developed for the small payload market. It's not reusable, in order to save on weight and cost, making it a cheap alternative for customers with tiny payloads, who would otherwise have to wait for YEARS for a space on a large rocket - piggy backing off of the main customer who's launching a huge payload.

The HAAS 2C means that the small payload customer, 1) doesn't have to wait years for a space on a traditional rocket, and 2) it would be cheaper than paying for a space on one of those rockets.

This is why you're complaint that it has a small payload, and is not re-usable is invalid. Also, I have a problem with you saying that SSTO's have re-usability as an inherent attribute. While most SSTO's have been designed that way, it doesn't mean that that is a hard and fast rule.

Those are my 2 cents. Otherwise, I found your presentation quite illumining and fun to watch.

Here is a question I have wondered about. Would a vehicle still be consider single stage if it lifted off as an aircraft, flew as an aircraft, including refueling as it got higher, then went into space as a rocket? There is a theoretical design for an engine which uses rocket inside a super critical jet engine. As a super critical engine it has no moving parts. Air is fired into the engine on the start and the engine fires. The air is compressed at the point the rocket thrust hits it and it becomes super hot. This causes it to expand much as a normal engine would do. This would cause a vacuum at the air intake and it would continue to get air.

It would then take off like an aircraft and very rapidly meet a tanker aircraft and refuel. It would then fly as high as a tank ac could and again refuel.

This means the size of the fuel tank is smaller, and thus your engine is smaller.

As the vehicle leaves the last refuel ac, its engine would get more air for a time as it accelerated. As it approached the limit of the air, resistance would drop, so it could lower its nose and accelerate using the air. When the speed was too high for even the thin air, it would bring its nose up and accelerate to orbital speed using just the engine.

In the lower atmosphere, it would be run on low thrust since most of the power would come form air expansion. As it reached vacuum, the vents that allowed air to enter the chamber would close and it would accelerate that way.

In college, I worked on the National Aerospace Plane project.  The best way to obtain SSTO is to have an air-breathing SCRAM jet power most of the flight.  Therefore, you don't have to lift as much oxidizer for your fuel.  Unfortunately, you have to reach near orbital velocities in a region of the atmosphere with some oxygen.  This creates an enormous amount of aerodynamic heating.  If I recall correctly, the heat flux on the leading edge of the wing was 10x the heat load of the space shuttle on re-entry.  That number was calculated by NASA in about 1990.

How would the 21st century Jules Verne approach work? A giant EM cannon shooting an SSTO-module as a projectile (almost) into orbit. The SSTO can then go beyond on its own and back. Heat and acceleration (if it has crew) may be way too much, but for unmanned payloads it might be worth pursuing?

I had to come back to this because I saw an otherwise reasonable video trying to say the key to personal spacecraft in the near future is SSTO's and scramjets. Looking into both, I realized that SSTO's can at least get very close to staged rockets, but ONLY if they used materials that are so light that adding engines for a second stage would offer a very small performance increase i.e. carbon nanotubes and aerogel. As for scramjets, they're great for missiles, but they are incredibly inefficient because of the supersonic combustion. The limiting factor is how much the air can be slowed down for efficient combustion without melting the engine. That's basically what the Skylon does by cooling the engine with the LH2, but it too is limited because it can only reach mach 5.4 in air breathing mode before the stresses become too great. Unless there's a way for them to at least double the top speed the engine can function at while using atmospheric oxygen, then there's no way it's going to be worth it. TL;DR, tanks are heavy, so don't carry them all the way; hybrid rocket engines are super efficient, but only work for a fraction of the flight.

If you try and send an SSTO rocket into space, its not going to work, as you say. But as you said in the beginning of the video, if we did try and build an SSTO, it would most likely have wings and at least 1 or possibly more air breathing engines, or again, as you mentioned, hybrid engines. Air breathing engines consume a lot less fuel, not to mention dont need oxidizer until they hit a point in the atmosphere, where your air intakes cant handle the demand of the engine. But getting up to an altitude of around 30,000 meters would be a lot easier and efficient with a winged craft with air breathing engines, and from there, not only could you then use the second half of your hybrid engine, but you'd start off with a not insignificant amount of horizontal speed. Also, the craft would be 100% reusable. But even if you can land the first, second or even third stage of a rocket, the fuel you'd need to land them, and the electronics and control surfaces\monopropellant you'd need to control them autonomously and land would compensate for the weight of the wings and possibly extra engines in case you dont want to use a hybrid, but in stead a set of both types of engines. So I disagree, that SSTOs suck, I just think we havent yet perfected the technology, and have a lot more invested in multi stage rocket engines. I bet I could whoop together a functioning SSTO in KSP, that would be cheaper to build, and would reach orbit just the same. Also, if this isnt enough to convince you, maybe this will. Landing a rocket, or deorbiting a rocket, you're going to use a loooot of fuel fighting gravity. But landing a winged craft, all you need to deal with is reentry, as the space shuttles did. And yes, they decommissioned the shuttle program, but that was decades ago, and technology has reached a point, where I dont think we'd run into any of the problems the shuttle program had to struggle with. So basically, if the skylon goes through to production, I think it's going to be more efficient and more cost effective than any multistage space craft we have now. Even if it takes time, I think its whats going to happen.

Note that there weren't any identified major problems with the OOST/ROMBUS or Nexus or the Boeing AMLLV or the Star Raker or the Boeing VTOL SSPS ferry. Nor the 2STO Sea Dragon.
As Robert Zubrin has said about NERVA, it represented an embarrassing excess of capability to an agency who had no post-Apollo ambition or direction.
They didn't work because they weren't tried. We can't say they couldn't or couldn't have worked.

It might be that the problem with SSTO is as Robert Truax found with rocketry in general when designing the Sea Dragon: If payload mass fraction sucks, then increase the size and you increase the payload.
He also established firmly that the cost for a large rocket is no more than for a small rocket of the same design. Size doesn't add much to cost but parts count, design margin and innovation are what drive up cost.

Thanks for the respectable discussion of the DC-X Project. I was on that team. Re-usability concepts were advanced dramatically during that program, and several team members later joined Blue Origin and SpaceX.

The only thing that stopped the DC-XA project was funding. And an engineer who forgot remove a safety pin to allow the fourth landing gear to drop. There were two previous "incidents" on the pad, which required extensive repair. That is what experimental vehicles are about: learning from mistakes, and getting better for the next test.

Of the three companies competing for the X-33 project in 1996, only McDonnell Douglas had a working, flying prototype. Rockwell blew the dust off a 1960's-era rocketplane paper project, and Lockheed Martin threw every advanced, barely (or not) tested tech into their proposal. Lockheed Martin won because of politics. McDonnell Douglas was losing military contracts, and eventually accepted a buy-out from Boeing.

I think the problem with fully reusable multistages is the lack of crossrange capability. Sure, if we had a one-world government or something, you wouldn't have to worry about your second stages landing in politically hostile territory, but we don't have that. And even if we did, there's simply some places that aren't easily accessible (or even suitable for landing). Good luck recovering your stage if its trajectory dictates it has to land on the side of a mountain, or in the middle of nowhere (or worse yet, land on the side of a mountain in the middle of nowhere).

Of course, the counter to this is just "load enough fuel on the stage so it can land somewhere better". But the obvious counterpoint to that is the rocket equation's tyranny. An SSTO obviously eliminates this. And, while they would have comparably bad payload capacities, you're saving a lot when you take the crossrange capability and full reuseability into account.

So sure, it'll take 500 launches to put something like another ISS into orbit. But unlike KSP, part count isn't a problem in reality, and you're not throwing away valuable engines on purpose, and not losing as many in accidents.

Tim, the major advantage of SSTOs (or, to be more exact, SSTOABs) that you have glossed over entirely is that they can take off from where they land—and do that quickly—because they don't need a booster to be made or transported there, cutting down on logistics and manufacturing facilities and expanding the range of intraplanetary use dramatically. This is the only reason the BFS orbital passenger transportation idea works at all—it cannot possibly transport people to random points on Earth if it requires a booster waiting fo it there to get it running again. The cost and wait times would make it entirely infeasible.

The main reason for using a spaceplane actually had nothing to do with the runways, since for example the Skylon has to use a special reinforced, extra long runway due to its huge weight. No, their main advantage is that countering so-called "gravity drag" is more efficient using lift than just normal reaction engines.
Also, the fuel tanks are suspended on the aeroframe, rather than being attached to the skin like in the SR-71, meaning that heat isn't so problematic as normal.

While not technically a single stage, Clarke's "Orion" space plane seems to tick many of these boxes as well.
In it's original configuration it was taken aloft by an air breathing supersonic lift plane not too dissimilar in concept to Virgin Galactic's version.
The main difference is that this was designed to take both the return vehicle as well as the Orion III to a high speed, high altitude horizontal trajectory prior to separation.
I think this concept really does need to be taken more seriously. Certainly more seriously than building 600 meter rocket simulations. I love your videos but I think showing that the needle rocket would crash due to lack of thrust was a waste of time. Better spent would have been to show how far a single stage rocket plane would have to fly horizontally before it had to transition upward to get out of the atmosphere due to heat.

Spending time optimizing this curve would yield more usable data to then turn around and make decisions about things like detachable wings that could self return and glide back to the launch facility or even having these wings be self powered.
The rational for this is pretty simple actually. While your needle rocket wouldn't move upwards, it would move along the ground if it were on railroad tracks.
So perhaps STO's are now and always will be impractical, Clarke's method certainly looks viable.
Anyway, enjoyed the video. Hopefully you will take another shot at this and perhaps examine some horizontal vehicles that have a partial unpowered or powered lift segment.

You have missed some of the worst problems with the SABRE/Skylon. As the design stands, it requires runways reinforced and heat resistant well beyond what the original spec was for the A380 and around 6 kilometers long. Public opinion is pretty much 100 % against them unfortunately, but a nuclear thermal rocket (I'm NOT talking about the nuclear micro-explosions stuff, Orion) could probably work quite well for an SSTO, because it only has to carry the working fluid, hydrogen. There is the weight of the fuel assembly and the shielding, to protect the crew from the direct shine from the engine of course. I tried to quickly find some power density figures for reactors, and I did find some data from the tests done in the second half of the 60s and early 70s. According to those the specific power of the reactors used then were in the 450 kW/kg range, with a thrust of 930 kN (reactor power was around 4.1 GW). That's about 9.5 tons for the engine (or at least the reactor). The thrust to weight ratio wasn't very good...But that was a long time ago. I wonder how far we could develop a nuclear atmospheric engine today. I find that very unlikely to happen though, due to public opinion on anything that has the word "nuclear" in it...

Ps.: Found a 1991 report on Project rover, the Phoebus-2A was the largest engine they built and tested, and produced the above cited 930 kN, continuously for 32 minutes, at a working fluid flow rate of 119 kg/s. The thrust in this case is comparable to a Merlin-1D (845 kN at sea level). Now from what I can gather, the Merlin-1D has a weight of around 630 kg, and a mass flow rate of 306 kg/sec. So for a 1 minute burn, the fuel+oxidizer mass for a Merlin-1D (2018) is about 18.3 tons, while for the nuclear thermal engine (1970) (just the working fluid, no need for an oxidizer), is about 7.2 tons. On the other hand the mass of the engine is a lot bigger for the nuclear variant, around 9.5 tons, which is 15 times that of the Merlin, which is a huge difference. So to actually start to have an advantage , and overcome the 8.9 tons of difference in weight, in propellant mass, it takes about 48 second of burn. So even in the first minute you are getting a payoff due to the much lower mass flow rate.

For an average FH 1st stage burn of 162 seconds, with 9 engines, the rockets use up a mixture of fuel and oxidizer of about 437400 kg, with a total engine mass of 5670 kg (a total of 443070 kg at takeoff). For the same "burn" the nuclear variant would require a total engine mass of 85500 kg (that's one hefty engine cluster), but would need only 175000 kg of propellant (a total of 260500 kg at takeoff). That's about 0.588x the liftoff weight. And here I've been comparing a nuclear engine design from 1970 to a state of the art chemical rocket engine of 2018 (and tried to push things so I error in favor of the chemical one). Shielding of course is not included in these calculation.

I agree that Single-stage-to-orbit reusable vehicles are awful in terms of their overall payload-to-orbit efficiency,  but why not use two back-to-back shuttle-like boosters (well, more like two VentureStar vehicles back-to-back) and go to orbit that way.  The first vehicle would supply the fuel to the engines of both vehicles during the first stage firing, then once its fuel was used up it would separate from the second stage and return back to a second ground base for landing and have a turbofan engine attached so it could fly back to the first base.  The second stage would ignite and continue into orbit to launch its payload.  In that way the first stage lands on a runway like a shuttle, and the second stage too lands back on a runway like a shuttle, except that the VentureStar uses a metal tile heat shield so it won't require so much 'refurbishing' after each flight.   No need to use untested Aerospike engines or risky composite fuel tanks, just use conventional engines either from Blue Origin or from Space-X and use the same aluminum alloy used on those vehicles also.

The failure of SSTOs is due to lack of funding and commitment, not due to technological limitations. Delta Clipper was perfectly capable of developing into a successful orbital rocket. It was suited for its mission of delivering multiple military satellites into custom orbits with only a few hours' notice and a day's turn-around time. NASA wasn't committed to the concept, though, so killed it at first excuse. It serves as inspiration for both SpaceX and Blue Origin rockets. Critically, it's advantages of reusability, simplicity and automation would have greatly lowered the cost of launching payloads into orbit, even below what SpaceX projects it could do in the near future.

I would love to hear move about the business case of Venture Star. The challenge that killed the program was not only a technical problem with the X-33 cracked composite hydrogen tank (which the engineers already solved in designs), but also a lack of future cash flows problem. The business case didn't exist, not enough customers who wanted to launch satellites on the platform which was to replace the space shuttle. Technology developed to where it was easy to put satellites in orbit without a crew. Crewing a launch vehicle is a cost driver, if the main benefit of using a SStO is cost saved due to re-usability, then an even better way to save cost is to do orbital missions without astronauts aboard, if possible. I wonder how an unscrewed version of Venture Star would fair in today's LEO satellite marketplace? My guess is still more expensive, even when reusability considered.

I figure we can continue using three-stage rockets to lift heavy payloads into orbit for building larger spacecraft. But I think it would be valuable to use the Skylon to ferry people into space, so they can board a NERVA-powered spaceship which doesn't land on Earth. Moon-mining could eventually lead us to the point where we can build the bulky hulls of spacecraft in low or zero gravity environments. Hydroponic farming technology will enable long-term habitation in space. Water is abundant throughout the outer solar system, and fuel materials are abundant from Mercury to Neptune. I think once we get stabilized habitation and production in space, it will become far easier to maintain, use, and grow the space program. At that point, SSTOs will likely be the most popular way to get people to and from Earth's surface.

Because let's face it, the space elevator will never work on Earth.

The main point of a single stage to orbit is to lower the cost of placing objects in orbit. It is a point you glossed over very lightly. That is the reason for having it launched vertically and return to a runway.
As long as the cost of launching objects into space remains above several hundred dollars a pound we will not be able to successfully colonize space.

Simply because today we are unable to manufacture materials that are strong and light enough doesn't mean that you can't in the future.

In mission 6 of the PS2 game Ace Combat 5: The Unsung War, there's an interesting variation on an SSTO launch. The launch vehicle is a cargo drone shuttle sent into low earth orbit to transfer a supply shipment to a "Manned Maneuverable Orbiting Spacecraft". The launch system uses a horizontal train rail a couple miles in length, ending in what looks like a 30-40 degree upward incline.
The shuttle rides on a rocket sled, until it reaches launch velocity pretty much at the end of the track, and be on an upward trajectory. After a brief pause, to let the sled fall away into the ocean on parachutes, the shuttle engines will ignite, taking it up to rendezvous with the orbital craft.
I dunno if such a thing would be possible in real life, but the mission always stuck in my mind as a rather interesting application of physics, along with having one of the most beautiful fictional craft I've seen, which you unfortunately have to shoot down in a later mission, mission 24.

Skylon's ascent is only about 15 minutes or something like that so unlike the Blackbird it's not flying to Russia and back. That's one aspect of the heat problem. The other is that it's full of liquid hydrogen, not kerosene so its tanks are going to stay cold and presumably that means they won't be expanding at all. The construction is also not aeroplane-like so the tanks won't be providing structural strength to the skin. It's supposed in fact to be more like an airship with an internal frame.  The outside will be a form of silicon carbide with a lot of insulation between it and the hydrogen tanks.  Skylon is too expensive to do in one jump so Reaction Engines are designing a modular family of engines (SABRE4) which can be scaled up and down in thrust by adding bits - this offers them the opportunity to share the engine development cost amongst several projects some of which will probably include hypersonic flight within the atmosphere.  Obviously there is some degree of military interest if they can demonstrate that their engine cycle works. There are 2 aspects that they are working to demonstrate now - the "HTX" or high temperature heat exchanger which cools incoming high speed air such that it won't melt the engine and the engine core.  The tests for the HTX were done with unheated incoming air some time ago and that demonstrated the anti-icing features. This test will be with hot incoming air that simulates the situation from 0 to roughly mach 5.  This is obviously critical to the whole engine so good results will advance their cause a lot but it's not the end. The other side of things is the engine core and it has to demonstrate their thermodynamic cycle which uses the heat rejected from the HTX to do work. I am not a rocket scientist but I understand that this cycle is very important to the efficiency of SABRE4. I am not at the moment even sure if they will be testing the combustion chambers as part of this - I think it' really about how they use their "Helium loop" that's carrying heat from the HTX to be dumped into fuel to drive a turbine and power other machinery. Assuming all of this gets done they still have to design the combustion chambers and engine nozzles (all intended to be based on well known technology) and an air intake that can do a transition from external to internal oxygen and all the things the SR-71 inlets had to deal with which is not easy.

What makes the rocket equation so tyrannical is that a linear increase in Delta-V requires an exponential increase in propellant. IOW, to double your Delta-V for a specific payload mass, you need e^2 (~7.3) times more propellant (more precisely, the ratio of propellant to dry mass - payload, tankage, engines - needs to be 7.3 times larger). To triple the Delta-V, you need e^3 (~20) times more propellant.

There's one, sort of, SSTO you didn't mention. That would be a magnetic accelerated ship launched from a vacuum tube on a mountain top on the equator. This has been studied extensively and is very feasible. The linear magnetic acceleration is roughly equivalent to a rail gun, but with a much larger projectile. By placing the launcher on a mountain top, you avoid a large part of the atmosphere. By putting the launcher on the equator and firing it East, you gain the maximum velocity from the Earth's rotation. By pumping the air out of the launch tube before firing, you avoid air resistance and air heating during the initial acceleration phase. Since the ship is accelerated to near orbital speeds inside the tube by magnetic force applied from ground based generators, the ship doesn't have to carry any fuel to get to orbit. It would have to have an engine and some fuel to stabilize the orbit and then to de-orbit the ship for landing, but that is far less than is required for a chemical launch system. The only problem with this type of SSTO is the crushing acceleration during launch. Even with a launch tube several miles long, the g forces generated would easily kill most human cargo. For this reason, this type of launch would only be for non-living cargo, but that is no problem since ships of this sort would be very cheap to build and they could be launched several times a day, limited only by the time it takes to recharge the launch gun and re-vacuum the tunnel. If the logistics of this type of launch seems too hard to overcome, just recall the Sprint missile built in 1972 which accelerated with over 100 g's of thrust and hit mach 10 in 5 seconds when fired from close to sea level, and this was while carrying sensitive electronics and instruments to allow it to intercept an incoming warhead. The magnetic launch ship would be fired from a mountain top in the Andes where the elevation of the mouth of the launch tube would be close to 19,000 feet high, which means the atmosphere density would only be a fraction of that at sea level, resulting in far less friction heating. If a Sprint could be built in 1972 and easily coped with that level of acceleration and heating, think how much easier it would be to build a magnetic launch ship today with 46 years newer technology and materials.

Not multi-stage but multi-phase. Use multiple engines for different flight regimes. The Skylon is an early example of this: get up to Mach 5 using the atmosphere, then fire rockets. But, more is possible. What if you replaced the core of a high-bypass turbofan with a "rocket in a box;" an internal rocket that fires through a turbine to run a fan at the front: Instant launch power. A bypass duct would allow a ramjet mode to get up to scramjet speeds, using it to reach the Skylon phase, but up to mach 10 or more. The body shape provides much of the engine's structure, so it doesn't rob too much space at the back. Once you're ready to ascend from the atmosphere, you fire the 'rocket in a box' again, but just to use thrust from the rocket. Another bypass mode would avoid spinning the fan (the multi-phase rocket/aero hybrid would likely be more complex than I suggest). Two engines, multiple phases. What do you think?

There are still a couple ways to extend the range of an SSTO. Instead of building different rockets for different stages, you could put both vacuum and atmospheric engines on the same stage; especially if you could scale the engines down in size.

Also, you don't HAVE to continuously accelerate something in flight to reach orbit; you just have to get it going sideways fast enough that it won't come back down. If you're feeling brave enough, you could use something like a mass driver to do that without even leaving the ground. Picking up speed magnetically on a circular track, it releases the spacecraft at orbital velocity; tangentially sending it off on its way up a ramp. Given enough extra speed to sacrifice to drag, the spacecraft could coast all the way up to Apogee, only requiring fuel on-board for the apogee kick and maneuvering.

Why don't you make a video about stage-and-a-half (1.5) designs? They do staging and only need one set of engines. Iterating on them  will get you the incremental benefits allowing for the SSTO with existing engine and materials technology. (Including use of the great lightweight heat shield tech. derived from the mismanaged X-33 dev. program.) 10 mton to LEO reusable in a vehicle the size of an F9 is possible (simply due to the small reduction in weight by eliminating the avionics and engine of the lower stage and the ability to use skinnier, lighter, non-structural drop tanks. In the complexity, weight, engine power, plumbing, and materials trade space, it works out nicely. The rocket equation has no issue with it, stability concerns, heat shield materials and other materials tech neither). 1.5 designs  make an excellent choice for versatile interplanetary SSTO's (that is SSTO at Moon/MARS and 1.5 stage on Earth) on the same vehicle. I have a design I am quite proud of, but there is also the non-pursued Russian MAKS 1.5. It all comes down to the rocket equation. You need a certain amount of Delta-V, no way around that.

The reason why it is so difficult is because chemical rockets have such low ISP. Double the ISP of the engine, and you can make a useful Earth-based SSTO without much difficulty. With a higher engine ISP, you can have a greater payload fraction from your rocket. Well, as long as you don't add too much extra mass along the way.

Many SSTO designs (or even reusable upper stage proposals) add a prohibitive amount of mass to the most important part of the rocket, the upper stage. Heat shields are heavy and fragile, but strictly necessary for returning from orbit. SSTOs, with their smaller mass fractions, compound the added-mass problem caused by thermal protection.

It's absolutely a solvable problem. Skylon's air-breating engines are a great example of one attempt at improving the engine ISP during a portion of the flight, however they add significant mass for gains that are too small to fully justify the penalties.

Another similar proposal would have used beamed-power from the ground (instead of chemical stored in the on-board fuel) to super-heat propellant for an ISP closer to 800. Sadly that project ran out of funding and failed, however the higher the ISP your engine can achieve, the more feasible it is to attempt an SSTO.
