Skylon is not directly comparable to the SR71 in terms of thermal expansion during airbreathing flight.

SR71 leaked because the tanks were integral to the plane's structure and were designed to seal at operating temperature, on the ground they leaked so the plane took off lightly loaded fueled and the accelerate to high speed.

The Skylon fuel tanks are not structural, they are thin aluminium balloon structures, the structural loads are carried by a carbon fibre truss which carries the ceramic skin, the skin can be shingled or have gap fillers to deal with thermal expansion.

The really nice thing about the design is that on reentry the vehicle is very light in comparison to it's volume it is about twice as big a a BFS but it's return mass is only 55,000kg. Thus it re-enters high so the thermal insulation does not have to have a high performance.

The key advantage that the Skylon is likely to have over BFS or equivalent is that horizontal landing is much less risky than propulsive so operating manned may be much easier.

Ok; great show. Except you forgot one possible SSTO that was proposed back in the 1970's that would have worked. First you need to understand that Specific Impulse is the key. Chemical rockets are limited to about 400. Max SP-Imp. But a Nuclear engine was demonstrated at 1,000 SP-Imp. At a thousand SP-Imp, an SSTO that would put a thousand tons into orbit and then land again is easy. And before you go crazy about Nuclear, the Hydrogen exhaust that created the thrusts was not radioactive in the least as the Hydrogen was not inside the reactor long enough. And that was using 1960's technology. Modern tech would produce a specific impulse around 2,000 easily making for big ships that could put 10,000 tons on the moon.  Though the engines have one drawback that they do require some shielding and must be isolated for a few weeks to cool down radioactively before they could be worked on. Though that depends on what nuclear fuel they use as A Thorium core that does not produce all the nasty radioactive particles that Uranium does would only need a few hours and be inert incase of an accident. Though even an uranium core was test dropped from high in the sky impacting the ground at thousands of miles an hour, survived without any uranium escaping. And was recovered days later without special shielding for the recovery crew..... Don't take my word for it check it out. But if you truly want to go to Mars and beyond we need to start thinking Nuclear engines.

Another good episode , although I think you're missing the point and comparing apples to oranges.  The SR-71 skin was made of titanium, not your typical heat resistance hull, the space shuttle on the other hand uses a ceramic composite, designed for extreme temperatures. The Skylon was also to use the ceramic design , but is also much lighter , so would only attain around half the heat load that of the space shuttle. So it could use the same tech without any special modification.  Now about the design of the plane with a rocket on it. I imagine this is due to the US military design of the aero spike and due to Brexit and loss of funding that had had to be picked up by BAE (A military company) and lost a few years , as testing was suppose to take place late 2016. Reaction Engines only gets a few millions in funding per year. SpaceX gets upwards of a billion by comparison. Reaction Engines has focused on getting the pre-cooler done. This is what makes it possible for a rocket to use normal atmosphere, reducing the size needed for oxygen in dense atmosphere levels. So if BAE lets REL do their own thing , I think it will be done by 2020 on target. But if BAE focuses on military design , it wont get done and the 2 stage aero spike design will takes it place advancing a totally different technology and effectively  killing the SSTO.  I hope they let them continue with current research that has been successful thus far.

Unlike the SR-71, Skylon's tankage is separate from it's skin. A framework of struts holds the skin outside, and the fuel tanks are able to freely move over the inner surface as the skin and struts expand. They thought of that.

While you mentioned the R-7, the closest we've had to an SST was the SM-65 Atlas D rocket, best known for Project Mercury. It was a "1 1/2" stage rocket, dropping off 3 tons of booster engine on the way up. Unlike the R-7,  Atlas kept its entire tank body, a stainless steel balloon with no frame,  all the way into orbit. The original R-7 got rid of 4 booster engines and their conical tanks, but the main central core went all the way into orbit. So, Sputnik 1 in October 1957 was actually accompanied in orbit by 7 tons of central core (stayed up for 2 weeks), while in December 1958 Project Score put a 4-ton Atlas B into orbit.  John Glenn was accompanied into orbit by two and a half tons of  booster.

I think the potential heat issue you see for the Skylon probably already has solutions for it.

For instance, the military of various major powers around the world have now been working on Scramjets for decades and those operate at at least as high a speed as Skylon does in air breathing mode, and some aim much faster. I haven't heard of leaking issues in the officially known test vehicles the USA used. And there are signs that at least some of these nations are getting closer to mass production as well, which would imply they're close or have reached a practical level already for materials that can handle the heat.

Secondly, Skylon uses an engine design that gives fairly high thrust to weight ratios. This means it shouldn't be staying at these speeds for all that long, thus giving less time to heat up. (The moment they reach speed, they'd switch to rocket mode to climb and accelerate further after all)

Thirdly the fuel is extremely cold (being liquid hydrogen) , which should allow them to use it to cool the exterior surface of the craft to an extent, it seems plausible that they could counteract major heating problems with that, especially as this is exactly what they're doing to keep the engine from melting as well.


Of course, even if the above is all true, it's still not the same as having built an actual functional plane yet. But the recent joining of several commercial partners is giving me the suspicion that either they're now willing to take a larger risk due to SpaceX, or that with the cooler design for the engine now showing promise that it will work in the real world, that the risks aren't as large any more.
(It's also worth noting the Skylon project is in a sense an extension of the Hotol project, which failed for various reasons, but I believe a major one was that they at the time couldn't make a good enough engine which thus the SABRE in theory resolves)



----

On a side note, a reusable SSTO in theory should have a faster turn around then a two stage reusable rocket. Which would let you more quickly recover capital costs and thus reduce overall running costs.(Because you don't have to put the two parts together constantly and the extra complications and risks this inevitably brings with it)

Still SSTO only really work if you can some how get sufficiently high ISP, otherwise the mass fraction just isn't good enough to compete with a multi-stage system. (Or if you can cheat yourself out of not needing to carry a lot of the fuel)

Since you talked about throttling, I was thinking about your comment on the Block5 video where you wondered about changing the chamber pressure... From an engineering perspective, I think that changing the chamber pressure is how they gained thrust.

Consider that you have to design the chamber pressure with a 15psi margin, because structurally it's about the difference between inside and outside... and at altitude that difference is 15psi larger due to having no atmospheric pressure..

If your max pressure is 190, then you have to be at 175 at sea level so that when your engine is running without atmospheric pressure, it doesn't exceed that max value.... BUT, if you can alter the chamber pressure then you can have the higher pressure at sea level, and back it off as you gain altitude... and over all, this will increase ISP, and thrust at sea level...

Just my hypothesis... :)

One thing that isn't quite accurate is the assumption that you need entirely different optimized engines for atmosphere or the vacuum of space. This isn't true at all, at least theoretically its not. On the fly optimization could be engineered as a flight control feature in the future. A rocket engine that changes its fuel/oxidizer/thrust specs/ratios on the fly doesn't seem to hard to figure out at this point. In fact it's probably just years away. So long humans continue to modernize and evolve and assuming we do not run out of resources I see no scientific reason that states we are not headed that way. One engine to rule them all that can land and take off from any surface in our solar system would be the ultimate goal for anyone seeking truly affordable reusable rocket ships. Let's not fall into the "it's not possible" group otherwise you stand to become one of the people who thought landing a rocket, on a barge, in the middle of the ocean was impossible. Look how that turned out... Lol
